content: The "Kids in Disasters Well-being, Safety, and Health Act of 2007" establishes the National Commission on Children and Disasters to focus on the well-being, safety, and health of children under 18 years of age. The National Commission on Children and Disasters aims to conduct a comprehensive study on children's needs in preparing for, responding to, and recovering from all hazards, including disasters and emergencies. It will review previous findings and submit a report with specific recommendations to the President and Congress. The National Commission on Children and Disasters will study children's needs in preparing for, responding to, and recovering from all hazards, including major disasters and emergencies. COMPOSITION OF COMMISSION. The National Commission on Children and Disasters is composed of 10 members appointed by various government officials, with the Chairperson and Vice-Chairperson elected from among the members. Governmental appointees cannot be federal officials or employees. The Commission is tasked with conducting a study on children's needs in preparation for, response to, and recovery from hazards, including disasters and emergencies. This includes examining physical and mental health, child care, welfare, education, housing, transportation, grant programs, juvenile justice, evacuation, and emergency management activities. The Commission is responsible for reviewing existing laws and lessons learned from past disasters to address the needs of children in emergency management. They will submit a report to the President and Congress with specific recommendations, including the establishment of a national resource center on children and disasters. The Commission will focus on coordinating resources and services for children in disasters, including administrative actions, policies, regulations, financing, and legislative changes. The Commission will have powers to coordinate resources and services for children in disasters, including administrative actions, policies, regulations, financing, and legislative changes. The Commission has the authority to conduct hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and receive necessary evidence to fulfill its functions under this Act. The Commission can request information and receive administrative support from federal agencies to carry out its duties in accordance with applicable laws and regulations. The Commission has the authority to enter into contracts, accept donations, and use postal services like a department or agency of the United States. SEC. 8. STAFF OF COMMISSION. The Chairperson of the Commission, with the Vice Chairperson, may appoint a staff director and necessary personnel to carry out functions. The compensation must adhere to regulations, and federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Commission without reimbursement. The Commission can procure consultant services from experts and consultants at rates not exceeding those of a person at level IV of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 9. TRAVEL EXPENSES. Each member of the Commission serves without compensation but receives travel expenses and per diem in accordance with government service provisions. SEC. 10. FEDERAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE ACT APPLICABILITY. The Federal Advisory Committee Act applies to the Commission and its staff. SEC. 11. REPORTS OF COMMISSION; TERMINATION. The Commission is required to submit an interim report by December 31, 2008, and a final report within 24 months of the Act's enactment. The Commission will terminate 180 days after submitting the final report, and all records will be transferred at that time. All records and papers of the Commission will be delivered to the Archivist of the United States for deposit in the National Archives. Authorization of appropriations for the Act is $2,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2008 and 2009.
